titleStmt.title: An Epigram to my friend the Author, of his namelesse Detractor before mentioned.

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: An Epigram to my friend the Author, of his namelesse Detractor before mentioned.

monogr.title: Essayes and characters, ironicall, and instrvctive : The second impression. With a new satyre in defence of common law and lawyers: mixt with reproofe against their common enemy. With many new characters, & diuers other things added; & euery thing amended. By Iohn Stephens the yonger, of Lincolnes Inne, Gent
monogr.author: Stephens, John

div.head: An Epigram to my friend the Author, of his namelesse Detractor before mentioned.

lg.l: Fastus disdaines thy worke, because not thine,
But meerly drawne forth by anothers line:
Thou imitat'st he saith: well thou mightstone:
For thou canst imitated be by none:
Though I dare take thy word, yea'tis well known
ther's nothing heer but thou maist call thine own.
For (like a common theefe) the sneaking elfe
Hath slander •… thee, that he might saue himselfe.

div.head: Aliud Epigramma ad Authorem delibro suo epulo assimulato.

lg.l: Why should'st thou striue or study to vpraise
A labour, how to work some Welchmens praise?
Those that haue iudgement must commend thy skill:
Regard not then though others say'tis ill:
If amongst many they dislike thy Feast,
A bitt of cheese will helpe them to digest.

div.head: Aliud ad eundem de detractore suo anonymo praedicto.

lg.l: For beare my freind to write against that man
A sharpe iambick, who hath wrong'd thy name:
Thou canst not right thy selfe; for he hath none:
Nor can haue, if he be the peoples Sonne.

closer.signed: GEO: GREENE of Lincolns Inne Gentleman.
